attributes.title: Terrorism and support for counterterrorist policies

q1.value: Terrorism and support for counterterrorist policies

q2.value: Dag Arne Christensen | Sveinung Arnesen | Jon Kåre Skiple | Jacob Sohlberg | Johan Martinsson | Gunnar Helgi Kristinsson | Gudbjorg Andrea Jonsdottir

q5.value: The study is a part of a project entitled “The Challenge from Terrorism in the Nordic Countries: An analysis of citizen’s reactions, policy responses and legitimacy”, financed by NordForsk (Grant number 88043)

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Democracies are under pressure from terrorist activities. Not only terrorist attacks, but also the sheer threat of terrorism places strains on democratic government (Davis et al. 2004; Dragu & Polborn 2014). Protection of citizens is a paramount task for the state. On the one hand, if citizens feel that law and order is under threat, the authority of government might possibly be undermined. On the other hand, measures to safeguard citizens against violent threats run the risk of weakening the very foundations of democracy. Stern policy measures like searches without warrants, arrests, telephone tapping, and prolonged detention without charge or trial may be rational methods for defending the safety of citizens, but they are also infringements on civil and political rights. Hence, the dilemma between security and freedom is most significantly felt in democratic states. There is a compelling need for more empirical knowledge about how democracies deal with this dilemma. To what degree are democratic states resilient in the sense that they are capable of sustaining freedom and civil rights when terrorism appears to threaten the safety of their citizens? How citizens perceive and react to terrorism is crucial for understanding democracies’ resilience against the challenge from terrorism. We therefore investigate how citizens perceive terrorism and under which conditions citizens support counterterrorist policies. Specifically, we’re interested in how attributes of both violent and non-violent incidents – including the type and severity, the target and location, and the social category of perpetrators and their motivation – affect citizens perceptions of incidents as terrorism and their support for preventive counterterrorist policies – including searches without warrants, telephone tapping, and prolonged detention without trial.

q16.value: We build on and extend Huff and Kertzer’s (2017) study of how American citizens define terrorism. Using a conjoint experiment, Huff and Kertzer (2017) show that American citizens categorization of incidents as acts of terrorism is influenced by the type and severity of violence, but also the attributed motivation for the incident and social categorization of the actor. In contrast to scholarly definitions of terrorism, the target and the location of the incident does not influence American citizens classification of the incident as terrorism. We seek to replicate these findings in the Nordic countries. Also, we test whether citizens support for various counterterrorist policies are affected by exposure to various violent and non-incidents. We will test the following hypothesis: H1: Violent tactics are more likely to be classified as terrorism than non-violent tactics H2: The higher the number of causalities, the more likely the incident is classified as terrorism H3: The target and location of incidents is not linked to classification of incidents as terrorism H4: Incidents performed by collectives are more likely to be classified as terrorism than incidents performed by individuals H5: Incidents carried out by actors with an identified social category are more likely to be classified as terrorism compared to incidents carried out by non-identified actors H6: Incidents motived by policy goals are more likely to be classified as terrorism than personal disputes. H7: Violent tactics are more likely to generate support for counterterrorist policies than non-violent tactics H8: The higher the number of causalities, the more support for counterterrorist policies H9: Incidents performed by collectives are more likely to generate support for counterterrorist policies H10: Incidents carried out by actors with an identified social category are more likely to generate support for counterterrorist policies H11: Incidents motived by policy goals are more likely to generate support for counterterrorist policies than personal disputes. We will also test the direct link between classifying incidents as terrorism and support for counterterrorist policies: H12: Citizens that define incidents as terrorism are more likely to support counterterrorist policies than citizens that do not. A related question which we will explore is whether there is an interaction effect between incident attributes and citizens perception of incidents as terrorism on support for counterterrorist policies. That is, citizens exposed to similar incident attributes may show higher support for counterterrorist policies depending on whether they perceive the incident as terrorism. We also plan to explore relevant heterogenous treatment effects. Citizens’ perceptions of certain incidents as terrorism may be affected by individual attitudes and background characteristics. Moreover, we may expect that the effect of incident attributes on citizens support for counterterrorist policies varies with individual attitudes and background characteristics. Two individual characteristics that are relevant are party preferences and gender.

q17.value: To test the effect of incident attributes on classification of incident as terrorism and public support for counterterrorist policies, we rely on a conjoint survey experiment. The design is a replication of Huff and Kertzer (2017) with two important differences. First, we have adjusted the design to make it suitable for the Nordic context. Second, we extended the design to measure outcome variables that measure public support for counterterrorist policies. Our conjoint experiment includes the following seven incident dimensions: tactic, target, location, casualties, actor description, actor type and actor motivation. The eight outcome variables are classification of incident as terrorism or not terrorism, and support for seven different counterterrorism policies: Keep people detained as long as they like without trial, tap people’s phone calls, randomly stop and search people on the streets, monitoring peoples e-mail and internet communication, monitor/wiretap rooms, close off parts of city spaces, let armed police or military patrol the streets To test h1:h6 we will estimate average marginal component effects (AMCE). The dependent variable is participants binary classification of incidents as terrorism or not terrorism. To test h7:h11 we will estimate AMCEs. The dependent variable is participants support for seven counterterrorist policies. As such, we will estimate seven different models. To test h12 we will estimate support for counterterrorist policies as a function of classifying incidents as terrorism using a regression models. We will control for potential confounders that may affect citizens classification of incidents as terrorism such as participants gender, policy preferences and personality traits. To explore interaction effects between incident attributes and classifying incidents as terrorism on support for counterterrorist policies we will estimate average component interaction effects (ACIE). To explore other heterogenous treatment effects we will estimate ACIEs.

q24.value: Pilot testing prior to data collection

registration_responses.q24: Pilot testing prior to data collection

attributes.title: Solar Villages Project: Understanding the Behavioral Impact of Solar Lanterns

q1.value: Solar Villages Project: Understanding the Behavioral Impact of Solar Lanterns

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The primary motivation for this project is to understand how the distribution of high-quality solar lanterns shapes household behavior in non-electrified habitations of rural India. The adoption of solar technology is growing rapidly across South Asia (Sovacool and Drupady 2011), and by 2030, o-grid solar technology is anticipated to compose 70% of the total increase in electricity access among households (SE4ALL 2014). While solar lanterns are an economically viable and environmentally friendly alternative to kerosene lighting in areas with poor electrification (Chaurey and Kandpal 2009; Palit 2013; Yoon, Urpelainen, and Kandlikar 2016; Urpelainen 2016), their use in rural India is correlated with village size and household wealth (Aklin, Cheng, and Urpelainen 2018). While a number of studies explore the bene ts of distributed solar power on rural households in South Asia (Komatsu, Kaneko, and Ghosh 2011; Brass et al. 2012; Samad et al. 2013), we know less about the specific household effects of solar lanterns, particularly among individuals who are not household heads such as married women and children.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 Treated households should have lower kerosene and other lighting expenditures than untreated households. Hypothesis 2 Treated households should have higher expenditure on food, consumer items (excluding the costs of lighting), visits to the doctor and the purchase of medicine, housing and durable goods, marriage and ceremonies (excluding the costs of lighting), inheritance/estate, repayment of debts, and other expenditures for normal consumption. Hypothesis 3 Treated households should use more hours of lighting per day. Hypothesis 4 Treated households should use fewer hours of kerosene, generator, liquified petroleum gas (LPG), and battery lighting per day. Hypothesis 5 Treated households should be more satisfied with their lighting. Hypothesis 6 Treated households should be more satisfied with their lighting for activities: reading, work, cooking, studying. Hypothesis 7 Treated households should have a more positive perception of solar technology. Hypothesis 8 Treated households should spend more time reading, working, and cooking at home. Children in treated households should spend more studying than children in untreated households. Hypothesis 9 Treated households should spend more time charging their mobile phones at home.

q17.value: We conduct our study using a sample of 200 non-electri ed households, drawn from 50 villages sampled from 537 in the Chunar Tehsil (subdistrict) in UP's Mirzapur district.1 The project is conducted in collaboration with the Solar Village Project (SVP), a non-pro t organization that assists families in India and Africa acquire, maintain and learn about solar power systems in homes with no other other power source. More information on the sampling and estimation strategy is available in the pre-analysis plan document.

attributes.title: Allies or Agitators? A Survey Experiment on Perceptions of Nonviolent Protest

q1.value: Allies or Agitators? A Survey Experiment on Perceptions of Nonviolent Protest

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Protests have been a major force in American history for bringing about political and social change. Yet public opinion about protests in U.S. history is best described as conflicted, and different traditions frame protests as conducive to advancing social progress or threatening to stability and the position of dominant groups. One common rationale used by elites for endorsing or suppressing social movements is whether they are predominantly (non)violent. In recent years, scholars have argued that nonviolent protests are more likely to succeed than violent ones due to the perceived legitimacy of nonviolence (Thomas and Louis 2013; Chenoweth and Stephan 2011; Schock 2005). However, research in cognitive psychology provides grounds to question whether an assessment of the intensity of tactics used in a protest—that is, how (non)violent they are—is independent of people’s prior political or ideological views. Experiments have shown that judgments about observable “facts” cannot be detached from preexisting biases and perceptual processes (Haidt 2001; Goff et al. 2014). Examples from different substantive areas illustrate how cognitive distortions can lead to pre-rational judgments and have real-world consequences. We propose a theory of protest perceptions that incorporates psychological findings on implicit cognitive biases, and argue that the assimilation of information about a protesting group precedes and shapes perceptions of how (non)violent it is, which in turn affects judgments about its merits. People’s first exposure to information about a mobilizing group—its demands, actions, and demographic makeup, for example—triggers an affective charge that is experienced as warm or cold feelings toward the group (Lodge and Taber 2005; Morris et al.2003; Redlawsk 2002). If prompted to render a judgment about the group’s interaction with the physical world, they will engage in motivated reasoning consistent with their initial charge (Lodge and Taber 2013). If a positive/negative response is triggered in a given instance, this effect can have implications for views on the legitimacy of protest more generally. We propose a causal chain in which the perceived level of (non)violence is endogenous to the interaction of a) information about a protesting group and b) partisan predispositions, which also shape policy views and abstract opinions about protests. Specifically, through the mediation of perceived violence, the interaction of tactics and partisan sentiments should be associated with c) immediate determinations of how to respond to protesters, d) attitudes on the importance of protest for democracy and e) support for punitive anti-protest policies in general.

q16.value: H1: The severity of protest tactics should be associated with the perceived level of violence H2: Respondents whose partisan preference is aligned with the protest group should perceive the level of violence of the protest as lower H3: Perceived level of violence should have a positive relationship on whether respondents think it is appropriate to arrest the organizers of the protest H4: Perceived level of violence should be negatively associated with whether respondents think protests are important for democracy H5: Perceived level of violence should be positive associated with support for punitive anti-protest policies in general

q17.value: We use an original fictional vignette within a survey experiment. Within the vignette—a description of a protest in the guise of a news story—we randomly assign varying protester group identity and tactical choices. To test our hypotheses, we intend to field a survey with an embedded experiment. It will be conducted on 1100 respondents on the Mechanical Turk platform, from which respondents are directed to the survey website. The vignette describes a fictitious protest and randomly assigns one of two protesting groups and one of three tactics, in a 2x3 fully crossed design. The vignette is as follows: A crowd of 200 people calling themselves [“Americans Against Racist Policing” / “Americans Against All Abortion”] gathered at city hall this morning. Larry Carter, 49, was among the participants. “Our political leaders are supposed to protect us, but they don’t. We are angry and feel our voices are not heard!” Carter said. When local officials refused to meet with the organizers, the group [held up placards and shouted slogans, some laced with profanity / blocked a nearby highway, bringing traffic to a standstill / threw rocks and other objects at the building]. All the elements in the vignette were chosen to isolate critical variables and minimize bias. Both “Americans Against Racist Policing” and “Americans Against All Abortion” were devised to refer to salient political issues that have generated real-life social movements. The former is reminiscent of Black Lives Matter and is associated with Democrats. The latter is not represented by a single major movement but is associated with Republicans. We use fictitious groups in order not to activate conscious associations with existing movements, yet we provide enough information for readers to be able to form an impression and render a judgment. The tactics in the vignette are typical of the repertoire of protests in the U.S. and are not associated with any party or faction. They represent gradations of direct action. Because the vignette does not state what the placards say or what damage, if any, is caused by throwing “rocks and other objects,” respondents must fill in the gaps in the narrative by imagining the contextual details. It is within the realm of possibility that certain kinds of profanity could be perceived as violent, while rocks that cause no injuries could be seen as nonviolent. There are five dependent variables that correspond to different steps in the theorized causal chain: First, we ask how the respondent would describe the intensity of the protest, on a scale from completely nonviolent to completely violent. Second, we ask how much the respondent agrees with the goals of the protest, which acts as a validity check on the correspondence between attitudinal factors and the information in the vignette, providing a measure of approval for the protesters apart from their tactics. Third, we ask whether it would be appropriate to arrest the protesters, which represents a “law-and-order” response. This measure is related to, but does not automatically follow from, perceptions of violence, as it may be possible to disapprove of the tactics used but favor a non-punitive response. Additional questions gauge how views about protests in general are shaped both by the treatments and by intervening variables that lie more proximate to the vignette. Thus, the fourth post-treatment question asks how much people “agree that protesters provide a useful service to our democracy,” which tests the extent to which exposure to a single episode of protest can tap into ostensibly deep-rooted philosophical beliefs. Fifth, we ask whether people would support a law punishing certain types of protest actions, the text for which was adapted from a bill proposed by Arizona legislators in early 2017 (Christie 2017). Views on this law indicate the extent to which perceptions of tactics or other aspects of the immediate episode can have broader public policy implications (Lodge and Taber 2013). The main independent variables are the six combinations of treatments. To test the effect of partisan bias, we interact party affiliation with the protest group treatment. In addition, we include psychological and demographic variables that may be associated with attitudes toward protest: child-rearing values (Stenner 2005), age, education, race, sex, and income. The survey instrument also includes two manipulation checks. Our analytical strategy is as follows. First, we present descriptive statistics and face validity checks. Then, since the dependent variables are ordinal Likert scales (e.g. strongly disagree to strongly agree), we test our claims using an ordinal logit model. We use weighted least squares with means and variance adjusted estimation (WLSMV), which performs better for categorical data (Beauducel and Herzberg 2006; Muthén and Asparouhov 2002). Finally, as the outcomes are sequential, we use a structural equation model to test paths of direct and indirect effects. We use the statistical software R for the ordinal logit models and Mplus 8 for the structural equation model.

attributes.title: Does exposure to an issue survey increase donor

q1.value: Does exposure to an issue survey increase donor

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The goal is to test the impact of exposure to a survey on donor behavior on a live federal campaign fundraising list. Campaigns frequently employ a "churn and burn" model for fundraising. In this model, email is a "one-way" channel of communication with little opportunity for campaign supporters to provide opinions to the campaign. The survey experiment provides a means to test an alternative to churn and burn in a live setting with permission from the campaign.

q16.value: H1a, b: Exposure to a survey embedded in a funding request will increase a) the probability of making a contribution and b) the amount contributed. RQ1a,b: Does the effect of the survey on a) the probability of making a contribution and b) the amount contributed differ for prior donors and non-donors?

q17.value: Randomization: Respondents were blocked on an indicator for prior contributions, and randomly assigned to treatment or control group. Regressing an indicator for treatment assignment on an indicator for prior contributions and fixed effects for zip code confirmed balance across treatment groups. Data: We plan to collect data on contributions after the request has been in the field for 48 hours. Based on prior requests, we anticipate that the lifecycle of a funding request lasts for 24-48 hours. Analysis: We plan to use linear regression to estimate the average treatment effect on two outcomes: (an indicator for donating or not) and natural log of (1 + total donations) for the time period in question. Outcomes will be regressed on an indicator for treatment (=1 for treatment, 0 for control), an indicator for prior donation, and fixed effects for zip code. Clustered standard errors will be estimated for coefficients. We will also conduct regressions with an interaction term for prior donation X treatment to explore whether the appeal had a different impact on people who contributed in the past.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

Campaigns frequently employ a "churn and burn" model for fundraising. In this model, email is a "one-way" channel of communication with little opportunity for campaign supporters to provide opinions to the campaign. The survey experiment provides a means to test an alternative to churn and burn in a live setting with permission from the campaign.

Based on prior requests, we anticipate that the lifecycle of a funding request lasts for 24-48 hours. Analysis: We plan to use linear regression to estimate the average treatment effect on two outcomes: (an indicator for donating or not) and natural log of (1 + total donations) for the time period in question. Outcomes will be regressed on an indicator for treatment (=1 for treatment, 0 for control), an indicator for prior donation, and fixed effects for zip code. Clustered standard errors will be estimated for coefficients. We will also conduct regressions with an interaction term for prior donation X treatment to explore whether the appeal had a different impact on people who contributed in the past.

attributes.title: Automated government decisions of asylum applications

q1.value: Automated government decisions of asylum applications

q5.value: This study is part of the Research Council of Norway’s project number 262986: “Can Fair Decision-Making Procedures Increase the Legitimacy of Democracies?”

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The primary scientific objective of the proposed study is to better understand how democratic institutions and decision-making bodies should organize decision-making procedures and implementation procedures in order to maintain legitimate governments in digitalizing societies. We are on the verge of a revolution in public sector decision-making processes, where computers will take over many of the governance tasks currently assigned to human bureaucrats. With it, the conditions for impartial and transparent treatment of citizens are changing. Increased capacity to process relevant information enhances the potential for making more accurate and efficient judgments. Yet, we also run the risk of creating a black box society where citizens are being kept in the dark about the governments’ decision-making processes that affect citizens’ lives. So, (how) does automated decisions affect the quality of government, and the government’s ability to implement policies in an unbiased manner? There is an imminent need to study these emerging governance developments from a political science perspective in general. This study contributes to such a research agenda, focusing on the citizen perspective by investigating how the public perceives automated decisions. Whereas the increased decision-making speed and efficiency is an unquestionable benefit, the rise of the public sector robots forces us to revisit other aspects regarding the relations between citizens and government. There is a growing awareness internationally concerning the need to study democratic principles such as fairness, accountability, and transparency which historically have been central concepts in the social sciences and psychology. What happens with the citizen-government link when the government official making not a human, but a robot?

q16.value: 1. We want to measure which decision procedure Norwegian citizens prefer that asylum applications are assigned to; manual processing by a human bureaucrat, or automatic processing by a robot. 2. We hypothesize that citizens care about equal treatment in government decisions, and that they therefore tend to want procedures that make few mistakes > H1: the share of errors associated with a decision procedure influences citizens’ readiness to change decision procedure. 3. We further want to study whether H1 is moderated by the type of decision procedure -- whether it is a manual or automatic procedure.. Whether or not there is such a moderating effect of decision procedure will yield important practical knowledge before automated decision procedures are implemented in governments. >H2: H1 is moderated by type of decision procedure.

q17.value: The study will test these hypotheses by fielding a conjoint survey experiment about an imagined asylum decision process in the Norwegian government. The vignettes vary in terms of attributes of the asylum seeker (gender, age, reason for fleeing, and whether the asylum seeker arrived with ID papers or not), as well as attributes related to the decision process (how many asylum seekers from the same country that have been granted access earlier that year, the type of decision process (automated or manual), whether the procedural errors concerned rejections or approvals of applications, and the share of decisions that were rebutted because of it). After reading the vignette, the respondent is asked to state whether s/he thinks the application should be processed manually or automatically. Please see the preanalysis plan for further vignette details in original language (Norway). The first measure of interest is which process is preferred among the respondents. This will be revealed through a univariate analysis of the post-measure variable. H1 will be tested by first creating a binary outcome variable that measures whether the respondents prefer the same procedure as in the vignette or a different one. This “change” variable is the dependent variable and the experimental stimulus is the vignette attribute that displays the share of errors connected to that procedure. The effect of errors on preferences for procedural change will be estimated with the Average Marginal Component Effect (AMCE). H2 will be tested by introducing the type of procedure (manual or automatic) as an interaction term.

q19.value: Estimated to ~1200. Sample size is not possible for researchers to manipulate.

q23.value: Ethics committee of The Norwegian Citizen Panel.

attributes.title: Growing Closer or Further Apart? Exposure to Social Media in Post-Conflict Settings

q1.value: Growing Closer or Further Apart? Exposure to Social Media in Post-Conflict Settings

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: The way in which a nation remembers contentious parts of its history and grieves victims from past violence can contribute or halt the reconciliation process, yet very little empirical evidence on inter-group dynamics during commemorative periods exists. We plan to test whether time spent on social media during war-related remembrance days, when ethnic identities are made salient and emotions heightened, can have a meaningful effect on group and political attitudes of the online users. The investigation takes place in Bosnia-Herzegovina from July 7 until July 14, three days before and three days after the commemoration day of genocide of 1995. Compared to the offline world, social media platforms facilitate more connections with weak ties - as a result, users are more likely to be exposed to the information and the interactions outside of the social group that they belong to. During the days of remembrance, the line between personal and political on Facebook is largely blurred; for that reason and based on annual trends within BiH, our expectation is that active Facebook users will be exposed, albeit in varying degrees, to content relating to the history of ethnic violence and current inter-group relations throughout this period. When faced with contentious content, individuals are prone to fallacy of composition, which in this case means that acts from an individual are used to update beliefs about the whole community. In the context of online social networks and ethnic divisions in particular, this is an equivalent of having a post from a member of a particular ethnic group lead an individual to update ones’ beliefs about the entire ethnic group. Our hypotheses are informed by studies suggesting that when faced with positive and negative content, adults display negativity bias in the formation of their final impressions and general evaluations.

q16.value: H1: Users who are not active on Facebook during the week of genocide commemoration will display more amicable inter-ethnic attitudes compared to their counterparts who remain active. H2: Users who are not active on Facebook during the week of genocide commemoration will display lower levels of political disaffection compared to their counterparts who remain active. Secondary hypotheses: H3: Users who are not active on Facebook during the week of genocide commemoration will display higher levels of subjective well-being compared to their counterparts who remain active. H4: Users who are not active on Facebook during the week of genocide commemoration will display lower level of news knowledge compared to their counterparts who remain active.

q17.value: Recruitment: (1) Online recruitment through Facebook ads, with the following text: ”Participate in a paid academic study on the effects on social media! Share your opinion, help advance knowledge and win 20KM of mobile credit! Press “Learn More” for additional information. “Clicking on Facebook ads will lead respondents to Qualtrics screening survey. (2) Offline recruitment by sharing flyers and getting in contact with local NGOs across the country to mobilize members of their communities. Pre-treatment survey questions: Respondents included in the study will be those who report that their average daily time spent on Facebook is more than 10 minutes, who report following at least one Bosnian politics Facebook page, and who are not frequently active on Twitter nor Reddit. This screening is crucial for ensuring that the participants are people who regularly spend time on Facebook (and are more likely to experience some difference when deactivating their account) and who do follow the news to some degree, making them more likely to be exposed to online inter-ethnic commentary and discussions. Sample from the group of interested participants, divide into treatment and control: (1) Treatment: Deactivate Facebook account, and complete a survey on July 14/15 (2) Control: Spend as much time as desired on Facebook, report time spent on Facebook. Both groups to fill out the final survey. Post-Treatment Measure/Outcome of Interest: Composite measures that we will create are the following: (1) ethnic divides: questions aimed at capturing subjects’ perception regarding one’s own ethnic group and regarding the members of the other ethnic groups; (2) political disaffection: questions aimed at capturing political cynicism, together with attitudes toward political engagement and optimism around the future of their country. We will also test two secondary outcomes: (3) news awareness and (4) subjective well-being.

attributes.title: The Effect of Treaty Ratification on Perceptions of Leaders and Torture: An MTurk Survey Experiment

q1.value: The Effect of Treaty Ratification on Perceptions of Leaders and Torture: An MTurk Survey Experiment

q5.value: The author acknowledges research funding from the School of Politics and International Relations, The Australian National University.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q16.value: Respondents who receive Article #2 (ratification vignette) will rate the President of Zimbabwe more favorably than do respondents in the control group. Respondents who receive Article #2 (ratification vignette) will believe it is less likely that torture is now occurring in Zimbabwe than do respondents in the control group. Respondents who receive Article #2 (ratification vignette) will believe that Zimbabwe’s reputation in the eyes of the international community is better than do respondents in the control group. Respondents who receive Article #2 (ratification vignette) will be less likely to believe that the use of torture is acceptable than do respondents in the control group.

q17.value: Simple t-tests, ordered probit, mediation analysis.

registration_responses.q1: The Effect of Treaty Ratification on Perceptions of Leaders and Torture: An MTurk Survey Experiment

attributes.title: Empathy and preferences for welfare assistance

q1.value: Empathy and preferences for welfare assistance

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Our experimental study evaluates the effect of an intervention that uses an essay writing task to facilitate perspective taking with people living in poverty. Following a rich literature that has successfully deployed such interventions to improve attitudes towards marginalized groups (Bruneau and Saxe, 2012; Galinsky and Moskowitz, 2000; Simonovits et al., 2018; Vescio et al., 2003) here we seek to encourage perspective taking with people in poverty in order to shift preferences about redistributive policies. Our theory suggests that one reason for the relatively low support for redistributive policies in the US is that large parts of society rarely consider the experiences of poor people. Accordingly, our intervention facilitates taking the perspective of an individual under financial hardship. It is reasonable to assume that the less likely a participant was to take the perspective of poor people before the experiment, the larger the effects of the intervention will be. Accordingly, our intervention may prove to be most effective among people (1) who are more affluent (2) do not consider themselves as poor and (3) have limited contact with poor people. In the limiting case, we clearly do not expect the treatment to have an impact on people who are experiencing economic hardship themselves.\footnote{This is analogous to perspective taking studies targeting prejudice against an ethnic minority only studying members of the ethnic majority.} Given that affluent people traditionally show low support for redistribution finding a larger treatment effect among them is of particular substantive relevance.

q16.value: H1. Perspective taking with people in poverty increases support for redistributive policies. H2. The marginal effect of perspective taking with people in poverty on redistributive policies is larger among more affluent participants than among less affluent participants.

q17.value: H1 will be tested by adjusted and unadjusted comparison of an index of redistributive preferences across experimental groups. H2 will be tested via regressions that estimate differences across experimental groups of the DV for different levels of income. See the PAP for more details.

registration_responses.q1: Empathy and preferences for welfare assistance
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

registration_responses.q17: H1 will be tested by adjusted and unadjusted comparison of an index of redistributive preferences across experimental groups. H2 will be tested via regressions that estimate differences across experimental groups of the DV for different levels of income. See the PAP for more details.

q5.value: The research was supported by the Grant K 120070 of the Hungarian Research, Development and Innovation Agency

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: It seems obvious that fear of the negative consequences of participation impede protest action. If there is a high chance of police attack on a public demonstration, sympathizers are less willing to participate. Research results, however, show a more complex picture. Sociologists and psychologists (e.g. Opp and Roehl 1990; Opp and Gern 1993; Opp 1994, Ayanian; Tausch 2016) reveal a positive correlation between perceived risks and participation in demonstrations. The more risky demonstrating is considered to be, the higher the willingness to participate. Although these results contradict the basic assumptions of sociologists' rational action theory, the risk-protest relation remains under-researched by political sociologists and social movement specialists. The aim of the project is to analyse the link between perceived risks and willingness to demonstrate. We will analyse whether the two different forms of the perceived risks (physical and non-physical retribution) increase or decrease the willingness to participate in government-critical demonstrations. Experiments on the risk-participation relation is rare, and focused solely on authoritarian, non-democratic regimes. Moreover, in those studies, only trait based measurement has been used to measure risk perception. In our study, instead, we induce risk perception by using vignettes.

q16.value: H1 (Influence of partisan identity hypothesis): The evaluation of information on current risks of participation in anti-government protests depends on partisan identity. Any such information increases (decreases) the stated risk perception of anti-government (pro-government) sympathizers. H2 (Rational choice hypothesis): The change of the perceived level of risk associated with participation in political protests is positively correlated with the change of the willingness to participate in such protests.

q17.value: The change of the perceived level of risk associated with participation in political protests is induced by a short vignette with a realistic description of punishment of opposition supporters participating in anti-government protests. We use two types of vignettes: (1) physical retribution: the text covers a story about police attacks, where protesters were beaten by police. (2) non-physical retribution: the text covers a story about an ordinary man, who was fired, because of his protest participation. Both stories based on real news reports, however we changed the names, and places. We distinguish anti-government and pro-government sympathizers. We expect that in the group of citizens with pro-government (anti-government) attitudes, information on current risks of participation in anti-government protests decreases (increases) the stated risk perception, and increases (decreases) willingness to participate in political protests. We define the two aforementioned groups by dichotomizing the answers to the following question: "If you think about the period since Viktor Orban has been elected in 2010, what would you say, how satisfied are you with the achievements of the government?" Dissatisfied scores (1 to 3) are coded as dissatisfied, anti-government attitude, and satisfied (5 to 7) are coded as satisfied, pro-government attitude. We compare these two groups (satisfied, pro-government and dissatisfied, anti-government groups) We use a buttery of risk perception indicators comprises 4 items. Finally, we measure willingness to participate in political demonstrations with the question: Would you or would you not to protest against a government action you strongly opposed? (on a scale of 1 to 6)

registration_responses.q5: The research was supported by the Grant K 120070 of the Hungarian Research, Development and Innovation Agency
